contentrichtext.text: {{Infobox mountain | name = Kusum Kanguru | photo = Kusum Kanguru SW face seen from Thado Koshi.jpeg | photo_caption = <small>Kusum Kanguru SW face</small> | elevation_m = 6367 | elevation_ref = <ref name=nma_peaks>{{cite web|url=http://www.nepalmountaineering.org/nma_peaks.php|title=NMA Peaks|publisher=[[Nepal Mountaineering Association]]|accessdate=2010-03-23}}</ref> | prominence_m = | prominence_ref = | map = Nepal | map_size = | label_position = left | translation = Three Snow-White Gods | language = [[Sherpa language|Sherpa]] | location = [[Khumbu]], [[Nepal]] | range = [[Himalayas|Charpati Himal]] | lat_d = 27 | lat_m = 43 | lat_s = 50 | lat_NS = N | long_d = 86 | long_m = 47 | long_s = 27 | long_EW = E | region = NP | coordinates_ref = | topo = | type = | age = | first_ascent = 7 October 1981 by Bill Denz (New Zealand). Solo ascent via SW buttress (W Face)<ref name="Himalayan Database">Himalayan Database</ref> | easiest_route = snow/ice climb }} '''Kusum Kanguru''' (alternatively '''Kusum Kangguru''', '''Kusum Kangru''', '''Kusum Kang''', '''Kusum Khangru''', '''Kusumkhang Karda''' or '''Mount Kanguru''') is a [[mountain]] in the [[Khumbu|Khumbu Region]] of the [[Himalayas|Himalaya]] in [[Nepal]]. Its name, '''Kusum Kanguru''', means "Three Snow-White Gods" in the [[Sherpa language]], which refers to the triple summit of the mountain. The main north-south ridge of Kusum Kanguru forms the border between the [[Dudh Khosi]] to the west and the [[Hinku Valley]] to the east. The mountain is the main source of the [[Kusum Khola]] (or Thado Koshi Khola) which flows westward to merge into the Dudh Khosi at the village of [[Thado Koshi]]. Kusum Kanguru is one of the first high snowy mountains that is seen when trekking from [[Jiri]] to [[Mount Everest]] base camp. ==Climbing history== With an altitude of 6,367 metres (6,369m or 6,370m according to other map sources),<ref name="Himalayan Database"/> the mountain is classified as a [[trekking peak]], but it is considered one of the most difficult to climb. Out of twenty two attempts between 1978 and 1998, nine successful expeditions have been reported.<ref name="Himalayan Database"/> After four previously unsuccessful attempts by British, Japanese and two prior New Zealand expeditions, a Japanese expedition lead by Ken Kanazawa reached the subsidiary northeast summit on 9 October 1979.<ref name="Himalayan Database"/> The first successful ascent of the main summit was made by Bill Denz of New Zealand on 7 October 1981, climbing the southwest buttress (west face), and descending the northwest flank. Denz did not only realise the first ascent, but also the first solo ascent and the first traverse of Kusum Kanguru. Five days later, on 12 October 1981, a Japanese team made the second ascent via the southeast face.<ref name="Himalayan Database"/> In the subsequent years, new routes have been opened, all of them technically very challenging. 1988 British Expedition led by Nick Mason conquered the previously unclimbed East Face. Expedition doctor was Rob Howarth who later worked in support of Everest Mountain Marathons. Expedition was filmed by Warwick Partington, former ITV & Channel 4 TV director before he later worked on Sky News. ==See also== * [[trekking peak|Nepalese trekking peaks]] * [[Geology of the Himalaya]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.alpinejournal.org.uk/Contents/Contents_1992-93_files/AJ%201992%2022-26%20Renshaw%20KKangguru.pdf Alpine Journal on the 1991 ascent via the south pillar (pdf)] * [http://www.sparc.org.nz/Documents/Hillary%20Expedition/New%20Zealand%20Solu%20Khumbu%20Alpine%20Style%20Expedition%20Sponsors%20-%20Final%20Report.pdf 2011 attempt by a New Zealand team (pdf)] [[Category:Mountains of Nepal]]
